accessibility.text: We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
GDP for a country that produces 100 computers  =$1,000(100) = $100,000
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
GDP for a country that produces 100 computers  =$1,000(100) = $100,000
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
GDP for a country that produces 100 pencils  =$0.5(100) = $50
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
GDP for a country that produces 100 pencils and 100 computers =$0.5(100) + $1,000(100) = 50 + 100,000= $100,050
Prices “weigh” goods according to value added: a computer sells for a higher price than a pencil, reflecting the difference in value added
We must use prices as weights when calculating GDP
GDP for a country that produces 100 pencils and 100 computers =$0.5(100) + $1,000(100) = 50 + 100,000= $100,050
Prices convert quantity produced into a dollar amount allowing us to add dollars: dollar amount of computers produced + dollar amount of apples produced + dollar amount of hair cuts…
